security: Revealing operational suggestions and contacts, especially those with potential influence on Fidel Castro or media figures like Herb Mathews and Edward R. Murrow, could compromise ongoing or future intelligence operations. The memo also mentions a State Department agent whose identity, if revealed, could endanger their security. Quoting directly: "Tichborn feels that the inducement of defactions could perhaps have more effect on Castro than any other single, rational action we might undertake," and "While in Cuba, Tichborn accidently met a young lady who later revealed to him that she was 'an agent for the State Department'."
summary: A memorandum summarizing the debriefing of Edward G. Tichborn(P) after his trip to Cuba, detailing his observations and suggestions regarding Fidel Castro, potential contacts of influence, and a possible State Department agent.
summary_one_paragraph: On February 2, 1960, Evalena S. Vidal documented the debriefing of Edward G. Tichborn(P) following his return from Cuba. Tichborn's observations included the disunity of opposition groups, Castro's sensitivity to defections, and a schism between Fidel and Raoul Castro, which suggested operational advantages. He identified individuals who might influence Fidel, such as Father Alberto de Castro, journalist Herb Mathews, Professor Rosco, and Edward R. Murrow. Tichborn also mentioned contact with a woman claiming to be a State Department agent and discussed arrangements for financial accounting and medical expenses.
title: Debriefing of Edward G. Tichbern(P)
